explanation.en: 'Abandon' means to leave or give up completely. 'Forsake' has the same meaning.
'Benevolent' means kind and helpful, so its opposite is 'Cruel'.
'Candid' means being open and honest in expression. 'Frank' is a synonym.
'Despise' means to feel contempt or deep dislike for someone, while 'Admire' is the opposite.
'Eloquent' describes someone who speaks fluently and persuasively.
'Futile' means incapable of producing any result; 'Effective' is the opposite.
'Hostile' means unfriendly or antagonistic; 'Aggressive' is similar in meaning.
'Impartial' means treating all sides equally; 'Biased' is its opposite.
'Lucid' means easily understood or clear.
'Melancholy' means deep sadness; 'Cheerful' is its opposite.
'Apathy' means lack of interest or emotion. 'Indifference' has the same meaning.
'Courage' means bravery; its opposite is 'Fear'.
'Diligent' means showing care and effort in work or duties. 'Hardworking' is the synonym.
'Enormous' means very large; 'Tiny' is its opposite.
'Frugal' means being careful about spending money; 'Economical' has a similar meaning.
'Harmony' means agreement or peace; 'Conflict' is the opposite.
'Impeccable' means perfect and without faults; 'Faultless' is the synonym.
'Jeopardy' means danger or risk; its opposite is 'Safety'.
'Meticulous' means showing great attention to detail; 'Thorough' is similar in meaning.
'Obsolete' means no longer in use or outdated; 'Modern' is the opposite.
'Alleviate' means to make pain or suffering less severe. 'Relieve' is the synonym.
'Belligerent' means hostile or aggressive; its opposite is 'Peaceful'.
'Cajole' means to persuade someone by flattery or gentle urging.
'Debacle' means a complete failure; its opposite is 'Success'.
'Erudite' describes someone who is highly educated or learned.
'Frivolous' means lacking seriousness or importance; 'Serious' is the antonym.
'Gregarious' means fond of company; 'Sociable' has the same meaning.
'Imminent' means about to happen soon; its opposite is 'Distant'.
'Nebulous' means unclear or vague.
'Prudent' means acting with care and thought for the future; 'Reckless' is its opposite.
'Abate' means to become less intense or widespread. 'Lessen' is the synonym.
'Meticulous' means showing great attention to detail; its opposite is 'Careless'.
'Ephemeral' means lasting for a very short time. 'Short-lived' is the synonym.
'Audacious' means showing a willingness to take surprisingly bold risks; its opposite is 'Timid'.
'Capitulate' means to cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand; 'Surrender' is the synonym.
'Fidelity' means faithfulness to a person, cause, or belief; its opposite is 'Treachery' (betrayal).
'Garrulous' means excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters. 'Talkative' is the synonym.
'Haughty' means arrogantly superior and disdainful; its opposite is 'Humble'.
'Pragmatic' means dealing with things sensibly and realistically; 'Practical' is the synonym.
'Obsolete' means no longer produced or used; out of date; its opposite is 'Modern'.
'Elucidate' means to make clear; 'Clarify' is the synonym.
'Pernicious' means having a harmful effect; its opposite is 'Beneficial'.
'Abridge' means to shorten a book, film, or speech without losing the sense. 'Shorten' is the synonym.
'Voracious' means having a very eager approach to an activity (like eating); its opposite is 'Satisfied'.
'Transient' means lasting only for a short time; 'Fleeting' is the synonym.
'Exalt' means to hold (someone or something) in very high regard; its opposite is 'Condemn' (express complete disapproval of).
'Acumen' means the ability to make good judgements and quick decisions; 'Insight' is the synonym.
'Sanction' can mean official permission or approval; its opposite is 'Prohibition'.
'Wane' means to decrease in vigour, power, or extent; 'Decrease' is the synonym.
'Fortuitous' means happening by accident or chance, often bringing good luck; its opposite is 'Unlucky'.
'Nefarious' means (typically of an action or activity) wicked or criminal. 'Wicked' is the synonym.
'Candid' means truthful and straightforward; its opposite is 'Deceptive' (misleading).
'Rescind' means to revoke, cancel, or repeal (a law, order, or agreement). 'Cancel' is the synonym.
'Brevity' means concise and exact use of words; its opposite is 'Lengthiness'.
'Ubiquitous' means present, appearing, or found everywhere. 'Omnipresent' is the synonym.
'Diligent' means having or showing care and conscientiousness in one's work; its opposite is 'Lazy'.
'Lethargic' means affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic. 'Sluggish' is the synonym.
'Placid' means (especially of a place or stretch of water) not easily upset or excited; its opposite is 'Turbulent' (characterized by conflict).
'Myriad' means a countless or extremely great number. 'Innumerable' is the synonym.
'Mitigate' means to make (something bad) less severe, serious, or painful; its opposite is 'Aggravate'.
'Zeal' means great energy or enthusiasm in pursuit of a cause or objective. 'Enthusiasm' is the synonym.
'Frugal' means careful in the use of resources; its opposite is 'Extravagant'.
'Conundrum' means a confusing and difficult problem or question. 'Mystery' is the synonym.
'Venerate' means regard with great respect; its opposite is 'Disdain' (contempt/lack of respect).
'Devoid' means entirely lacking or free from. 'Lacking' is the synonym.
'Debilitate' means to make (someone) weak and infirm; its opposite is 'Strengthen'.
'Sanguine' means optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently bad or difficult situation. 'Optimistic' is the synonym.
'Perilous' means full of danger or risk; its opposite is 'Safe'.
'Innumerable' means too many to be counted. 'Many' is the synonym.
'Ameliorate' means to make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better; its opposite is 'Worsen'.
'Clemency' means mercy or lenience. 'Mercy' is the synonym.
'Akin' means of similar character. 'Different' is the antonym.
'Incorrigible' means not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed. 'Unmanageable' is the synonym.
'Hinder' means to create difficulties for (someone or something), resulting in delay or obstruction; its opposite is 'Facilitate'.
'Envisage' means to contemplate or to form a mental picture of something. 'Visualize' is the synonym.
'Overt' means done or shown openly; its opposite is 'Secret'.
'Panacea' means a solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases. 'Cure-all' is the synonym.
'Recalcitrant' means having an obstinately uncooperative attitude; its opposite is 'Obedient'.
'Pristine' means in its original condition; unspoiled. 'Spotless' is the synonym.
'Apathy' means lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern; its opposite is 'Enthusiasm'.
'Succinct' means briefly and clearly expressed. 'Pithy' is the synonym.
'Malignant' means harmful or evil in nature; its opposite is 'Beneficial'.
'Alacrity' means brisk and cheerful readiness. 'Eagerness' is the synonym.
'Ostentatious' means characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; its opposite is 'Modest'.
'Furtive' means attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble. 'Secretive' is the synonym.
'Jubilant' means feeling or expressing great triumph and joy; its opposite is 'Depressed'.
'Confluence' means the junction of two rivers, especially rivers of approximately equal width. It is generally used to mean a coming together or 'Meeting'.
'Exonerate' means to absolve (someone) from blame for a fault or wrongdoing; its opposite is 'Condemn'.
'Perfunctory' means (of an action or gesture) carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection. 'Cursory' is the synonym.
'Innocuous' means not harmful or offensive; its opposite is 'Toxic'.
'Surreptitious' means kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of. 'Secret' is the synonym.
'Dogmatic' means asserting opinions as facts; its opposite is 'Open-minded'.
'Ambitious' means having or showing a strong desire and determination to succeed. 'Driven' is the synonym.
'Disparage' means to regard or represent as being of little worth; its opposite is 'Praise'.
'Vivid' means producing powerful feelings or strong, clear images in the mind. 'Clear' is the synonym.
'Paltry' means small or meagre; its opposite is 'Substantial'.
'Inadvertent' means not resulting from or achieved through deliberate planning. 'Unintentional' is the synonym.
'Ephemeral' means lasting for a very short time; its opposite is 'Permanent'.
'Augment' means to increase the amount or size of something. 'Increase' is the synonym.
'Tacit' means understood or implied without being stated; its opposite is 'Explicit'.
'Capricious' means given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behaviour. 'Fickle' is the synonym.
'Acuity' means sharpness or keenness of thought, vision, or hearing; its opposite is 'Dullness'.
'Emanate' means (of a feeling, quality, or atmosphere) to issue or spread out from (a source). 'Issue' is the synonym.
'Inept' means having or showing no skill; its opposite is 'Skilful'.
'Ponder' means to think about (something) carefully, especially before making a decision or reaching a conclusion. 'Consider' is the synonym.
'Mellifluous' means (of a voice or words) sweet or musical; pleasant to hear; its opposite is 'Harsh'.
'Adept' means very proficient or expert in something. 'Skilled' is the synonym.
'Profound' means very great or intense; its opposite is 'Shallow'.
'Cajole' means to persuade someone to do something by sustained coaxing or flattery. 'Persuade' is the synonym.
'Miserly' means characterized by or indicative of lack of generosity; its opposite is 'Generous'.
'Incessant' means (of something regarded as unpleasant) continuing without pause or interruption. 'Ceaseless' is the synonym.
'Vex' means to make (someone) feel annoyed or frustrated; its opposite is 'Soothe'.
'Glib' means (of words or the person speaking them) fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow. 'Fluent' is the synonym.
'Mitigate' means to make (something bad) less severe; its opposite is 'Worsen'.
'Parsimonious' means extremely unwilling to spend money or use resources. 'Stingy' is the synonym.
'Fiasco' means a thing that is a complete failure; its opposite is 'Success'.
'Avarice' means extreme greed for wealth or material gain. 'Greed' is the synonym.
'Languid' means (of a person or manner) relaxed and peaceful, often listless; its opposite is 'Energetic'.
'Heresy' means belief or opinion contrary to orthodox religious (especially Christian) doctrine. 'Dissent' is the synonym.
'Ephemeral' means lasting for a very short time; its opposite is 'Permanent'.
'Cynical' means believing that people are motivated purely by self-interest; distrustful of human sincerity. 'Pessimistic' is the synonym.
'Placate' means to make (someone) less angry or hostile; its opposite is 'Provoke'.
'Abstain' means to formally choose not to do something. 'Refrain' is the synonym.
'Deteriorate' means to become progressively worse; its opposite is 'Improve'.
'Indolent' means wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy. 'Lazy' is the synonym.
'Pious' means devoutly religious; its opposite is 'Irreligious'.
'Reticent' means not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily. 'Quiet' is the synonym.
'Stagnant' means (of a body of water or the atmosphere of a confined space) having no current or flow and often having an unpleasant smell as a consequence; its opposite is 'Flowing'.
'Vilify' means to speak or write about in an abusively disparaging manner. 'Defame' is the synonym.
'Turbulent' means characterized by conflict, disorder, or confusion; its opposite is 'Peaceful'.
'Quell' means to put an end to (a rebellion or other disorder), typically by the use of force. 'Suppress' is the synonym.
'Ameliorate' means to make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better; its opposite is 'Worsen'.
'Pernicious' means having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual or subtle way. 'Damaging' is the synonym.
'Garrulous' means excessively talkative; its opposite is 'Reticent' (not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily).
'Felicitous' means well chosen or suited to the circumstances; apt. 'Apt' is the synonym.
'Chastise' means to rebuke or reprimand severely; its opposite is 'Praise'.
'Pugnacious' means eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight. 'Belligerent' is the synonym.
'Exorbitant' means (of a price or amount charged) unreasonably high; its opposite is 'Reasonable'.
'Voracious' means having a very eager approach to an activity, especially eating. 'Ravenous' is the synonym.
'Tractable' means (of a person or animal) easy to control or influence; its opposite is 'Stubborn'.
'Clemency' means mercy or lenience. 'Mercy' is the synonym.
'Indigenous' means originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; its opposite is 'Alien' (foreign or external).
'Jubilant' means feeling or expressing great triumph and joy. 'Happy' is the synonym.
'Adept' means very proficient or expert in something; its opposite is 'Clumsy'.
'Pristine' means in its original condition; unspoiled. 'Unspoiled' is the synonym.
'Apathy' means lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern; its opposite is 'Enthusiasm'.
'Recalcitrant' means having an obstinately uncooperative attitude. 'Resistant' is the synonym.
'Overt' means done or shown openly; its opposite is 'Secret'.
'Wane' means to decrease in vigour, power, or extent. 'Decrease' is the synonym.
'Fidelity' means faithfulness to a person, cause, or belief; its opposite is 'Treachery' (betrayal).
'Furtive' means attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt. 'Secretive' is the synonym.
'Haughty' means arrogantly superior and disdainful; its opposite is 'Humble'.
'Ubiquitous' means present, appearing, or found everywhere. 'Omnipresent' is the synonym.
'Transient' means lasting only for a short time; its opposite is 'Permanent'.
'Abrogate' means to formally abolish or annul (a law, right, or agreement). 'Abolish' is the synonym.
'Ambitious' means having a strong desire to succeed; its opposite is 'Apathetic' (showing no interest or concern).
'Sanction' can mean official permission or approval. 'Permission' is the synonym.
'Frugal' means careful in the use of money or resources; its opposite is 'Extravagant'.
'Debilitate' means to make (someone) weak and infirm. 'Weaken' is the synonym.
'Sagacious' means having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgement; wise or shrewd; its opposite is 'Foolish'.
'Abridge' means to shorten a book, film, or speech without losing the sense. 'Shorten' is the synonym.
'Diligent' means having or showing care and conscientiousness in one's work; its opposite is 'Lazy'.
'Lethargic' means affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic. 'Sluggish' is the synonym.
'Venerate' means regard with great respect; its opposite is 'Disdain' (contempt/lack of respect).
'Acumen' means the ability to make good judgements and quick decisions. 'Insight' is the synonym.
'Myriad' means a countless or extremely great number; its opposite is 'Few'.
'Envisage' means to contemplate or to form a mental picture of something. 'Visualize' is the synonym.
'Perilous' means full of danger or risk; its opposite is 'Safe'.
'Elucidate' means to make (something) clear. 'Clarify' is the synonym.
'Sanguine' means optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently difficult situation; its opposite is 'Pessimistic'.
'Nefarious' means (typically of an action or activity) wicked or criminal. 'Wicked' is the synonym.
'Candid' means truthful and straightforward; its opposite is 'Deceptive' (misleading).
'Rescind' means to revoke, cancel, or repeal (a law, order, or agreement). 'Cancel' is the synonym.
'Brevity' means concise and exact use of words; its opposite is 'Lengthiness'.
'Conundrum' means a confusing and difficult problem or question. 'Mystery' is the synonym.
'Meticulous' means showing great attention to detail; its opposite is 'Careless'.
'Devoid' means entirely lacking or free from. 'Lacking' is the synonym.
'Obsolete' means no longer produced or used; out of date; its opposite is 'Modern'.
'Zeal' means great energy or enthusiasm in pursuit of a cause or objective. 'Enthusiasm' is the synonym.
'Ameliorate' means to make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better; its opposite is 'Worsen'.
'Placid' means (especially of a place or stretch of water) calm and peaceful, with little movement or activity. 'Calm' is the synonym.
'Audacious' means showing a willingness to take surprisingly bold risks; its opposite is 'Timid'.
'Capitulate' means to cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand. 'Surrender' is the synonym.
'Exalt' means to hold (someone or something) in very high regard; its opposite is 'Condemn'.
'Fortuitous' means happening by accident or chance rather than design. 'Accidental' is the synonym.
'Hinder' means to create difficulties for, resulting in delay or obstruction; its opposite is 'Facilitate'.
'Innumerable' means too many to be counted (many). 'Many' is the synonym.
'Akin' means of similar character; its opposite is 'Different'.
'Panacea' means a solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases. 'Cure-all' is the synonym.
'Abate' means to become less intense or widespread; its opposite is 'Intensify'.
'Pragmatic' means dealing with things sensibly and realistically. 'Practical' is the synonym.
'Succinct' means briefly and clearly expressed; its opposite is 'Verbose' (using or expressed in more words than are needed).
'Ephemeral' means lasting for a very short time. 'Short-lived' is the synonym.
'Alacrity' means brisk and cheerful readiness; its opposite is 'Reluctance'.
'Malignant' means harmful or evil in nature. 'Lethal' is the synonym.
'Ostentatious' means characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; its opposite is 'Modest'.
'Confluence' means the junction of two things, generally a coming together or 'Meeting'.
'Perfunctory' means (of an action or gesture) carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection; its opposite is 'Thorough'.
'Exonerate' means to absolve (someone) from blame for a fault or wrongdoing. 'Acquit' is the synonym.
'Inept' means having or showing no skill; its opposite is 'Skilful'.
'Vivid' means producing powerful feelings or strong, clear images in the mind. 'Clear' is the synonym.
'Dogmatic' means asserting opinions as facts; its opposite is 'Open-minded'.
'Capricious' means given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behaviour. 'Fickle' is the synonym.
'Paltry' means small or meagre; its opposite is 'Substantial'.
'Disparage' means to regard or represent as being of little worth; 'Criticize' is a close synonym.
'Acuity' means sharpness or keenness of thought; its opposite is 'Dullness'.
'Emanate' means to issue or spread out from (a source). 'Issue' is the synonym.
'Mellifluous' means sweet or musical; pleasant to hear; its opposite is 'Harsh'.
'Ponder' means to think about (something) carefully. 'Consider' is the synonym.
'Profound' means very great or intense; its opposite is 'Shallow'.
'Glib' means fluent and voluble. 'Fluent' is the synonym.
'Vex' means to make (someone) feel annoyed or frustrated; its opposite is 'Soothe'.
'Parsimonious' means extremely unwilling to spend money or use resources. 'Stingy' is the synonym.
'Languid' means relaxed and peaceful, often listless; its opposite is 'Energetic'.
'Avarice' means extreme greed for wealth or material gain. 'Greed' is the synonym.
'Heresy' means belief or opinion contrary to orthodox religious doctrine; its opposite is 'Orthodoxy' (generally accepted theory/belief).
'Incessant' means continuing without pause or interruption. 'Ceaseless' is the synonym.
'Mitigate' means to make (something bad) less severe; its opposite is 'Worsen'.
'Jubilant' means feeling or expressing great triumph and joy. 'Happy' is the synonym.
'Miserly' means characterized by lack of generosity; its opposite is 'Generous'.
'Cynical' means distrustful of human sincerity. 'Pessimistic' is the synonym.
'Deteriorate' means to become progressively worse; its opposite is 'Improve'.
'Indolent' means wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy. 'Lazy' is the synonym.
'Pious' means devoutly religious; its opposite is 'Irreligious'.
'Reticent' means not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily. 'Quiet' is the synonym.
'Stagnant' means having no current or flow; its opposite is 'Flowing'.
'Vilify' means to speak or write about in an abusively disparaging manner. 'Defame' is the synonym.
'Turbulent' means characterized by conflict, disorder, or confusion; its opposite is 'Peaceful'.
'Placate' means to make (someone) less angry or hostile. 'Appease' is the synonym.
'Quell' means to put an end to (disorder); its opposite is 'Incite' (to encourage or stir up).
'Pugnacious' means eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight. 'Belligerent' is the synonym.
'Tractable' means easy to control or influence; its opposite is 'Stubborn'.
'Felicitous' means well chosen or suited to the circumstances; apt. 'Apt' is the synonym.
'Chastise' means to rebuke or reprimand severely; its opposite is 'Praise'.
'Pernicious' means having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual or subtle way. 'Damaging' is the synonym.
'Garrulous' means excessively talkative; its opposite is 'Reticent'.
'Voracious' means having a very eager approach to an activity, especially eating. 'Ravenous' is the synonym.
'Exorbitant' means (of a price or amount charged) unreasonably high; its opposite is 'Reasonable'.
'Akin' means of similar character. 'Related' is the synonym.
'Clemency' means mercy or lenience; its opposite is 'Cruelty'.
'Indigenous' means originating or occurring naturally in a particular place. 'Native' is the synonym.
'Recalcitrant' means having an obstinately uncooperative attitude; its opposite is 'Obedient'.
'Apathy' means lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern. 'Indifference' is the synonym.
'Pristine' means in its original condition; unspoiled; its opposite is 'Dirty'.
'Overt' means done or shown openly. 'Open' is the synonym.
'Wane' means to decrease in vigour, power, or extent; its opposite is 'Increase'.
'Fidelity' means faithfulness to a person, cause, or belief. 'Faithfulness' is the synonym.
'Ubiquitous' means present, appearing, or found everywhere; its opposite is 'Rare'.
'Ambitious' means having a strong desire to succeed. 'Driven' is the synonym.
'Abrogate' means to formally abolish or annul; its opposite is 'Establish'.
'Debilitate' means to make (someone) weak and infirm. 'Weaken' is the synonym.
'Sanction' can mean official permission or approval; its opposite is 'Prohibition'.
'Frugal' means careful in the use of money or resources. 'Thrifty' is the synonym.
'Lethargic' means lacking in energy; its opposite is 'Active'.
'Sagacious' means having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgement; wise or shrewd. 'Shrewd' is the synonym.
'Abridge' means to shorten; its opposite is 'Lengthen'.
'Myriad' means a countless or extremely great number. 'Innumerable' is the synonym.
'Elucidate' means to make (something) clear; its opposite is 'Obscure'.
'Perilous' means full of danger or risk. 'Hazardous' is the synonym.
'Diligent' means careful and conscientious; its opposite is 'Lazy'.
'Rescind' means to revoke, cancel, or repeal. 'Cancel' is the synonym.
'Candid' means truthful and straightforward; its opposite is 'Deceptive'.
'Acumen' means the ability to make good judgements and quick decisions. 'Insight' is the synonym.
'Brevity' means concise and exact use of words; its opposite is 'Lengthiness'.
'Nefarious' means wicked or criminal. 'Wicked' is the synonym.
'Obsolete' means no longer produced or used; its opposite is 'Modern'.
'Conundrum' means a confusing and difficult problem or question. 'Mystery' is the synonym.
'Meticulous' means showing great attention to detail; its opposite is 'Careless'.
'Ameliorate' means to make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better. 'Improve' is the synonym.
'Zeal' means great energy or enthusiasm; its opposite is 'Apathy' (lack of interest or enthusiasm).
'Devoid' means entirely lacking or free from. 'Lacking' is the synonym.
'Placid' means calm and peaceful; its opposite is 'Turbulent'.
'Audacious' means showing a willingness to take surprisingly bold risks. 'Bold' is the synonym.
'Fortuitous' means happening by accident or chance, often bringing good luck; its opposite is 'Unlucky'.
'Abate' means to become less intense or widespread. 'Lessen' is the synonym.
'Capitulate' means to cease to resist or surrender; its opposite is 'Fight' or resist.
'Haughty' means arrogantly superior and disdainful. 'Arrogant' is the synonym.
'Garrulous' means excessively talkative; its opposite is 'Reticent'.
'Incorrigible' means not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed. 'Unmanageable' is the synonym.
'Exalt' means to hold (someone or something) in very high regard; its opposite is 'Condemn'.
'Dilatory' means slow to act. 'Slow' is the synonym.
'Amorphous' means without a clearly defined shape or form; its opposite is 'Defined'.
'Assiduous' means showing great care and perseverance. 'Diligent' is the synonym.
'Efficacy' means the ability to produce a desired or intended result; its opposite is 'Failure'.
'Insipid' means lacking flavour or zest. 'Bland' is the synonym.
'Jettison' means to throw or drop (something) from an aircraft or ship; its opposite is 'Retain'.
'Lugubrious' means looking or sounding sad and dismal. 'Mournful' is the synonym.
'Malign' means evil in nature or effect; its opposite is 'Praise'.
'Pithy' means (of language or style) brief but full of substance and meaning. 'Concise' is the synonym.
'Replete' means filled or well-supplied with something; its opposite is 'Empty'.
'Vacillate' means to alternate or waver between different opinions or actions. 'Waver' is the synonym.
'Transient' means lasting only for a short time; its opposite is 'Permanent'.
'Wary' means feeling or showing caution about possible dangers or problems. 'Cautious' is the synonym.
'Zealous' means having or showing great energy or enthusiasm; its opposite is 'Apathetic'.
'Invective' means insulting, abusive, or highly critical language. 'Abuse' is the synonym.
'Magnanimous' means generous or forgiving; its opposite is 'Selfish'.
'Ponderous' means slow and clumsy because of great weight. 'Bulky' is the synonym.
'Reclusive' means avoiding the company of other people; its opposite is 'Sociable'.
'Salient' means most noticeable or important. 'Prominent' is the synonym.
'Tantamount' means equivalent in seriousness to; its opposite is 'Unequal'.
'Ephemeral' means lasting for a very short time. 'Fleeting' is the synonym.
'Ubiquitous' means present, appearing, or found everywhere; its opposite is 'Rare'.
'Fastidious' means very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail. 'Careful' is the synonym.
'Ameliorate' means to make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better; its opposite is 'Worsen'.
'Garrulous' means excessively talkative. 'Talkative' is the synonym.
'Exonerate' means to absolve (someone) from blame; its opposite is 'Condemn'.
'Heresy' means belief or opinion contrary to orthodox doctrine. 'Dissent' is the synonym.
'Meticulous' means showing great attention to detail; its opposite is 'Careless'.
'Inadvertent' means not resulting from or achieved through deliberate planning. 'Unintentional' is the synonym.
'Tacit' means understood or implied without being stated; its opposite is 'Explicit'.
'Languid' means having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort. 'Sluggish' is the synonym.
'Mitigate' means to make (something bad) less severe; its opposite is 'Worsen'.
'Obsolete' means no longer produced or used; out of date. 'Outdated' is the synonym.
'Miserly' means characterized by lack of generosity; its opposite is 'Generous'.
'Overt' means done or shown openly. 'Open' is the synonym.
'Placate' means to make (someone) less angry or hostile; its opposite is 'Provoke'.
'Ponder' means to think about (something) carefully. 'Consider' is the synonym.
'Wary' means feeling or showing caution; its opposite is 'Reckless'.
'Reticent' means not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily. 'Quiet' is the synonym.
'Sanguine' means optimistic or positive; its opposite is 'Pessimistic'.
'Stagnant' means having no current or flow. 'Motionless' is the synonym.
'Venerate' means regard with great respect; its opposite is 'Disdain'.
'Turbulent' means characterized by conflict, disorder, or confusion. 'Violent' is the synonym.
'Akin' means of similar character; its opposite is 'Different'.
'Vilify' means to speak or write about in an abusively disparaging manner. 'Defame' is the synonym.
'Wane' means to decrease in vigour, power, or extent; its opposite is 'Increase'.
'Abstain' means to formally choose not to do something. 'Refrain' is the synonym.
'Pious' means devoutly religious; its opposite is 'Irreligious'.
'Acuity' means sharpness or keenness of thought. 'Sharpness' is the synonym.
'Glib' means fluent and voluble (often insincere); its opposite is 'Stammering' (halting speech).
'Hinder' means to create difficulties for, resulting in delay or obstruction. 'Impede' is the synonym.
'Capricious' means given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behaviour; its opposite is 'Stable'.
'Indigenous' means originating or occurring naturally in a particular place. 'Native' is the synonym.
'Cynical' means distrustful of human sincerity; its opposite is 'Optimistic'.
'Nefarious' means wicked or criminal. 'Wicked' is the synonym.
'Avarice' means extreme greed for wealth; its opposite is 'Generosity'.
'Panacea' means a solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases. 'Cure-all' is the synonym.
'Paltry' means small or meagre; its opposite is 'Substantial'.
'Placid' means calm and peaceful. 'Calm' is the synonym.
'Vex' means to make (someone) feel annoyed or frustrated; its opposite is 'Soothe'.
'Pristine' means in its original condition; unspoiled. 'Unspoiled' is the synonym.
'Dilatory' means slow to act; its opposite is 'Punctual'.
'Quell' means to put an end to (disorder). 'Suppress' is the synonym.
'Audacious' means showing a willingness to take bold risks; its opposite is 'Timid'.
'Recalcitrant' means having an obstinately uncooperative attitude. 'Resistant' is the synonym.
'Assiduous' means showing great care and perseverance; its opposite is 'Careless'.
'Rescind' means to revoke, cancel, or repeal. 'Cancel' is the synonym.
'Insipid' means lacking flavour or zest; its opposite is 'Flavoursome'.
'Tractable' means (of a person or animal) easy to control or influence. 'Docile' is the synonym.
'Lugubrious' means looking or sounding sad and dismal; its opposite is 'Cheerful'.
'Zeal' means great energy or enthusiasm in pursuit of a cause or objective. 'Enthusiasm' is the synonym.
'Haughty' means arrogantly superior and disdainful; its opposite is 'Humble'.
'Furtive' means attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt. 'Secretive' is the synonym.

**'Jubilant'** means feeling or expressing great happiness and triumph; its opposite is **'Depressed'**.

**'Avarice'** means extreme greed for wealth or material gain. **'Greed'** is the synonym.

**'Cajole'** means to persuade someone to do something by sustained flattery or coaxing. **'Coax'** is the synonym.
**'Debilitate'** means to make (someone) very weak; its opposite is **'Strengthen'**.
**'Efface'** means to erase or make oneself appear insignificant. **'Erase'** is the synonym.
**'Fecund'** means producing or capable of producing an abundance of offspring or new growth; its opposite is **'Barren'**.
**'Gratuitous'** means uncalled for; lacking good reason; unjustified. **'Unjustified'** is the synonym.

**'Lackadaisical'** means lacking enthusiasm and determination; carelessly lazy. **'Careless'** is the synonym.

**'Noxious'** means harmful, poisonous, or very unpleasant. **'Poisonous'** is the synonym.
**'Ostentatious'** means characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; its opposite is **'Modest'**.
**'Placate'** means to make (someone) less angry or hostile. **'Pacify'** is the synonym.
**'Redolent'** means strongly reminiscent or suggestive of (something); its opposite is **'Smelly'** (in the sense of not being pleasantly scented or reminiscent).
**'Serene'** means calm, peaceful, and untroubled. **'Calm'** is the synonym.
**'Sublime'** means of very great excellence or beauty; its opposite is **'Inferior'**.
**'Turgid'** means swollen and distended or excessively grand or complex in language. **'Swollen'** is the synonym.
**'Veracity'** means conformity to facts; accuracy; its opposite is **'Falsehood'**.
**'Vicarious'** means experienced in the imagination through the feelings or actions of another person. **'Indirect'** is the synonym.
**'Wanton'** means (of a cruel or violent action) deliberate and unprovoked; its opposite is **'Justifiable'**.
**'Zenith'** means the highest point reached by a celestial or any other object. **'Peak'** is the synonym.

**'Disparage'** means regard or represent as being of little worth; its opposite is **'Praise'**.

**'Furtive'** means attempting to avoid notice or attention; secretive. **'Secretive'** is the synonym.

**'Lascivious'** means (of a person, manner, or gesture) feeling or revealing an overt and often offensive sexual desire; its opposite is **'Chaste'**.
**'Mellifluous'** means (of a voice or words) sweet or musical; pleasant to hear. **'Harmonious'** is the synonym.
**'Obdurate'** means stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action; its opposite is **'Compliant'**.
**'Opulent'** means rich and luxurious or lavish. **'Wealthy'** is the synonym.
**'Parsimonious'** means extremely unwilling to spend money or use resources; its opposite is **'Generous'**.
**'Perfunctory'** means (of an action or gesture) carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection. **'Cursory'** is the synonym.

**'Adept'** means thoroughly proficient or expert. **'Skilled'** is the synonym.

**'Elucidate'** means to make (something) clear. **'Clarify'** is the synonym.
**'Fickle'** means changing frequently, especially as regards loyalties or interests; its opposite is **'Constant'**.
**'Gaffe'** means an unintentional act or remark causing embarrassment; a blunder. **'Blunder'** is the synonym.
**'Haughty'** means arrogantly superior and disdainful; its opposite is **'Humble'**.
**'Imbibe'** means to absorb or assimilate (ideas or knowledge) or to drink. **'Absorb'** is the synonym.
**'Juxtapose'** means to place or deal with close together for contrasting effect; its opposite is **'Separate'**.
**'Laconic'** means (of a person, speech, or style of writing) using very few words. **'Concise'** is the synonym.
**'Munificent'** means more generous than is usual or necessary; its opposite is **'Stingy'**.
**'Nefarious'** means wicked or criminal. **'Wicked'** is the synonym.

**'Perennial'** means lasting or existing for a long or apparently infinite time; enduring or continually recurring. **'Everlasting'** is the synonym.
**'Quiescent'** means in a state or period of inactivity or dormancy; its opposite is **'Active'**.
**'Recalcitrant'** means having an obstinately uncooperative attitude towards authority or discipline. **'Defiant'** is the synonym.
**'Sardonic'** means grimly mocking or cynical; its opposite is **'Sincere'**.

**'Ubiquitous'** means present, appearing, or found everywhere. **'Omnipresent'** is the synonym.
**'Vacuous'** means having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence; mindless; its opposite is **'Intelligent'**.

**'Alacrity'** means brisk and cheerful readiness; its opposite is **'Reluctance'**.

**'Ephemeral'** means lasting for a very short time; its opposite is **'Permanent'**.
**'Fatuous'** means silly and pointless. **'Silly'** is the synonym.
**'Garrulous'** means excessively talkative; its opposite is **'Quiet'**.
**'Hegemony'** means leadership or dominance, especially by one state or social group over others. **'Dominance'** is the synonym.
**'Inane'** means silly or senseless; its opposite is **'Profound'**.
**'Insipid'** means lacking vigour or interest. **'Boring'** is the synonym.
**'Jocose'** means playful or humorous; its opposite is **'Serious'**.
**'Lascivious'** means (of a person, manner, or gesture) feeling or revealing an overt and often offensive sexual desire. **'Lustful'** is the synonym.
**'Meticulous'** means showing great attention to detail; its opposite is **'Sloppy'**.
**'Oblique'** means neither parallel nor at a right angle to a specified or implied line; slanting. **'Slanting'** is the synonym.
**'Pedantic'** means excessively concerned with minor details; its opposite is **'Informal'**.
**'Prevaricate'** means speak or act in an evasive way; to lie. **'Lie'** is the synonym.
**'Recondite'** means little known; obscure; its opposite is **'Simple'**.
**'Specious'** means superficially plausible, but actually wrong or misleading. **'Misleading'** is the synonym.
**'Superfluous'** means unnecessary, especially through being more than enough; its opposite is **'Essential'**.
**'Temperate'** means showing moderation or self-restraint. **'Moderate'** is the synonym.
**'Undermine'** means to lessen the effectiveness, power, or ability of; its opposite is **'Support'**.
**'Vituperative'** means bitter and abusive. **'Abusive'** is the synonym.
**'Wistful'** means having or showing a feeling of vague or regretful longing; its opposite is **'Joyful'**.
**'Amalgamate'** means to combine or unite to form one organization or structure. **'Combine'** is the synonym.
**'Befuddle'** means to make (someone) unable to think clearly; its opposite is **'Clarify'**.
**'Clemency'** means mercy or lenience. **'Mercy'** is the synonym.
**'Dormant'** means temporarily inactive or asleep; its opposite is **'Active'**.
**'Exigent'** means demanding or crucial. **'Crucial'** is the synonym.
**'Fallow'** means (of farmland) ploughed and left unseeded for a season; its opposite is **'Productive'**.
**'Frivolous'** means not having any serious purpose or value. **'Trivial'** is the synonym.
**'Gaudy'** means extravagantly bright or showy; its opposite is **'Plain'**.
**'Inculcate'** means to instil (an attitude, idea, or habit) by persistent instruction. **'Instil'** is the synonym.
**'Insurgent'** means a rebel or revolutionary; its opposite is **'Loyalist'**.
**'Lugubrious'** means looking or sounding sad and dismal. **'Mournful'** is the synonym.
**'Mellifluous'** means (of a voice or words) sweet or musical; its opposite is **'Discordant'**.
**'Nascent'** means (especially of a process or organization) just beginning to come into existence and showing signs of future potential. **'Developing'** is the synonym.
**'Petulant'** means (of a person or their manner) childishly sulky or bad-tempered; its opposite is **'Good-humored'**.
**'Pernicious'** means having a harmful effect. **'Harmful'** is the synonym.
**'Redundant'** means not or no longer needed or useful; its opposite is **'Necessary'**.
**'Sycophancy'** means obsequious flattery. **'Flattery'** is the synonym.
**'Tenet'** means a principle or belief; its opposite is **'Doubt'**.
**'Trenchant'** means vigorous or incisive in expression or style. **'Incisive'** is the synonym.
**'Unequivocal'** means leaving no doubt; unambiguous; its opposite is **'Ambiguous'**.
**'Vacuous'** means having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence; mindless. **'Mindless'** is the synonym.
**'Voluminous'** means occupying or containing much space; its opposite is **'Small'**.
**'Absolve'** means to set free from blame, guilt, or responsibility. **'Acquit'** is the synonym.
**'Befall'** means (of something bad) to happen to someone; its opposite is **'Avert'**.
**'Clairvoyant'** means a person who claims to have a supernatural ability to perceive events in the future or beyond normal sensory contact. **'Psychic'** is the synonym.
**'Delineate'** means to describe or portray precisely; its opposite is **'Obscure'**.
**'Effigy'** means a sculpture or model of a person. **'Model'** is the synonym.
**'Eschew'** means deliberately avoid using; its opposite is **'Embrace'**.
**'Fulsome'** means complimentary or flattering to an excessive degree. **'Excessive'** is the synonym.
**'Impetuous'** means acting or done quickly without thought or care; its opposite is **'Cautious'**.
**'Invidious'** means likely to arouse resentment or anger in others, especially unfairly. **'Unpleasant'** is the synonym.
**'Lackadaisical'** means lacking enthusiasm and determination; its opposite is **'Enthusiastic'**.
**'Malediction'** means a magical word or phrase uttered with the intention of bringing about evil or destruction; a curse. **'Curse'** is the synonym.
**'Nefarious'** means wicked or criminal; its opposite is **'Virtuous'**.
**'Obsequious'** means obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree. **'Servile'** is the synonym.
**'Pellucid'** means translucently clear; its opposite is **'Opaque'**.
**'Ponderous'** means slow and clumsy because of great weight. **'Bulky'** is the synonym.
**'Quixotic'** means exceedingly idealistic; its opposite is **'Practical'**.
**'Rancour'** means bitterness or resentfulness. **'Bitterness'** is the synonym.
**'Salubrious'** means health-giving; its opposite is **'Harmful'**.
**'Succinct'** means briefly and clearly expressed. **'Concise'** is the synonym.
**'Taciturn'** means reserved or uncommunicative in speech; its opposite is **'Talkative'**.
**'Vacillate'** means to alternate or waver between different opinions or actions. **'Waver'** is the synonym.
**'Vicissitude'** means a change of circumstances or fortune; its opposite is **'Stability'**.
